newsitem.title: USA: Veritas shares soar on Sun Microsystems software pact.
newsitem.headline: Veritas shares soar on Sun Microsystems software pact.

text.p: The stock of Veritas Software Corp. surged 15 percent Wednesday after Sun Microsystems Inc. said it agreed to ship Veritas products with its computer disk drive storage systems.
The agreement will bring in as much as $2.5 million in additional revenue for Veritas by the fourth quarter, said Veritas Chief Executive Mark Leslie.
The stock of Veritas, based in Mountain View, Calif., jumped $6.75 to $51 on Nasdaq trading of 1.14 million shares.

Under the agreement, Sun, which specialises in making computers for storing and retreiving information on networks, will pack specialised versions of Veritas' disk and information management software with its computers.
Sun also will sell some Veritas products under its own brand, the companies said.
The agreement helped Veritas regain much of the loss its stock price suffered two weeks ago when it announced plans to acquire OpenVision Technologies Inc. for about $400 million.
"The investment world looked at the OpenVision merger and looked at the Sun agreement and is now able to see all of the pieces that we see," Leslie said.

The agreement with Sun will likely generate an additional $1 million in sales of Openvision products and an additional $1.5 million of Veritas products per quarter by the end of the year, Leslie said.

In the most recently reported quarter ended Sept. 30, Veritas had revenue of $9.5 million and net income of $3.13 million, or 22 cents a share. Sun officials could not be reached immediately for comment.
